title-group.article-title: Cassane diterpenoids from the seeds of Caesalpinia bonduc and their nitric oxide production and α-glucosidase inhibitory activities

Cassane diterpenoids from the seeds of
Caesalpinia bonduc
and their nitric oxide production and α -glucosidase inhibitory activities

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Caesalpinia bonduc
(L.) roxb.
Cassane diterpenoids
α -glucosidase inhibitory activity
Nitric oxide (NO) inhibitory activity
A B S T R A C T

Ten previously undescribed cassane diterpenoids, cassabonducins A–J, and eleven known compounds were isolated from the seeds of
Caesalpinia bonduc
. The structures of the undescribed compounds were elucidated by extensive analysis of spectroscopic data (IR, HRESIMS, and 1 H, 13 C and 2D NMR) and their absolute configurations were determined by the ECD data and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. ε -Caesalpin-VII was obtained from natural resources for the first time. Cassabonducin A possessed noteworthy inhibitory activity against LPS-induced nitric oxide (NO) production in RAW 264.7 macrophages with IC 50 value of 6.12 μM. Cassabonducin D and neocaesalpin N showed moderate α -glucosidase inhibition at the concentration of 50 μM with inhibitory capacities of 47.17% and 43.83%, respectively.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
The genus
Caesalpinia
belongs to the Fabaceae family and comprises approximately 100 species that are commonly distributed in tropical and subtropical regions of the world, including 20 species found in China (
). Several
Caesalpinia species
, such as
C. sappan
L.,
C. bonduc
(L.) Roxb.,
C. minax Hance
, and
C. decapetala (Roth) Alston
are used in Chinese folk medicine for the treatment of anemopyretic cold, dysentery, swollen boils, bruises, and venomous snake bite (
; Editorial
). Especially,
C. sappan
L. ( Fabaceae ), known as a red dyestuff, is widely used in traditional Chinese medicine to treat menorrhalgia, cardiovascular, and cerebrovascular diseases (
). Previous studies on the chemical constituents from the
Caesalpinia
genus have led to the isolation of cassane diterpenoids, triterpenoids, steroids, flavonoids, lignans, phenylpropanoids, and alkaloids (
;
). The cassane diterpenoids are mainly and characteristically chemical components of
Caesalpinia
and have a wide range of biological activities bioactivities, including anti-inflammatory, antitumor, antimalarial, antiviral, antioxidant, and antimicrobial properties (
).

sec.title: 2.1. Structural elucidation
sec.p:
Cassabonducin A ( 1 ) was obtained as colorless crystals, whose molecular formula was established as C 26 H 32 O 9 by the pseudomolecular ion peak at m/z 511.1950 [M+Na] + (calcd 511.1939) in HRESIMS spectrum, implying eleven degrees of unsaturation. The IR absorptions indicated the presence of hydroxy ( 3439 cm -1 ), carbonyl (1781 and 1747 cm 1 ), and double bond ( 1632 cm 1 ) functionalities. The 1 H NMR spectroscopic data ( Table 1 ) displayed diagnostic signals of an exocyclic methylene [ δ H 5.76 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, H-17a) and 5.43 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, H-17b)], two trisubstituted double bond [ δ H 6.16 (t, J =1.3, Hz, H-15) and 5.74 (t, J =2.0, Hz, H-11)], three oxymethines [ δ H 5.66 (t, J =11.0 Hz, H-7), 5.62 (d, J =11.0 Hz, H-6), and 5.09 (t, J =3.2 Hz, H-1)], and three methyl groups [ δ H 1.27 (s, H 3 -20), 1.11 (s, H 3 -18), and 1.10 (s, H 3 -19)]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra exhibited 26 carbon signals ( Table 2 ), categorized into three methyls, three methylenes (one olefinic carbon at δ C 117.4), seven methines (two olefinic carbons at δ C 111.8 and 108.5, and three oxygenated carbons at δ C 76.5, 74.8, and 74.3), and seven nonprotonated carbons (one oxygenated carbon at δ C 80.3, three olefinic carbons at δ C 154.7, 152.4, 138.1, and one carbonyl at δ C 171.6), and three acetyl groups ( δ C 172.4 and 21.1; 172.1 and 21.7; 171.6 and 21.0). The aforementioned spectroscopic analysis suggested that 1 was a cassane diterpenoid. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data of 1 were similar to those of neocaesalpin AF (
). The notable discrepancy involved that the methyl moiety at C- 14 in neocaesalpin AF was replaced by an exocyclic double bond in 1 , which was evidenced by key HMBC ( Fig. 2 ) correlations of H-17a and H-17b with C-8 ( δC 45.4) and C-14 ( δC 154.7).
a Measured at 500 MHz.
b Measured at 600 MHz.
3 C
a Measured at 125 MHz. b Measured at 150 MHz.

The relative configuration of 1 was established by analysis of the ROESY data ( Fig. 3 ) and coupling patterns of related protons. The ROESY cross-peaks of H-1/H 3 -20, H-6/H 3 -20, H-6/H-8, and H 3 -19/H 3 - 20 indicated they were co-facial and adopted the β -orientations. The coupling constants of J 6, 7 (11.0 Hz) and J 8, 9 (11.0 Hz) suggested that H-7 and H-9 were α -axially orientated. However, the ROESY spectrum couldn’ t provide sufficient information to assign the configuration of C-5. Fortunately, a colorless crystal of 1 was obtained from MeOH, and the α -orientation of 5-OH were determined by X-ray diffraction (Cu K α ) analysis ( Fig. 4 ). It was noteworthy that a small Flack parameter 0.01 (6) in the final refinement permitted the determination of the absolute configurations of 1 as 1 S ,5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,8 S ,9 S , 10 S (
). Therefore, the structure of 1 was elucidated as (1 S ,5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,9 S , 10 S )-5-hydroxy-1,6,7-triacetoxycassa-11,13(15),14(17)-trien-16, 12-olide.

Cassabonducin B ( 2 ) was obtained as a colorless oil. The positive-ion HRESIMS data revealed an [M+Na] + ion peak at m/z 497.2153 (calcd 497.2146), consistent with the molecular formula C 26 H 34 O 8, corresponding to ten degrees of unsaturation. Its IR spectrum exhibited absorption bands for hydroxy (3440 cm-1 ), conjugated carbonyl ( 1747 cm 1 ), and benzene ring (1627 and 1480 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 2 displayed the signals of one aromatic proton at δ H 6.33 (b rs, H-11), six aromatic carbons at δ C 158.2, 142.4, 133.0, 125.1, 124.3, and 102.2, and two aliphatic methylenes at δ C 71.0 and 29.3 ( Tables 1 and 2 ), indicating the presence of a benzodihydrofuran ring in 2 . The remaining 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 2 displayed the signals of three acetyl groups [ δ H 2.07 (s), 2.01 (s), and 1.99 (s); δ C 169.8 and 21.0, 170.1 and 20.9, 169.7 and 21.3], four tertiary methyls, three aliphatic methylenes, three oxygenated methines [ δ H 5.91 (d, J = 3.1 Hz, H-1), 5.67 (t, J =3.1 Hz, H-2), and 5.22 (d, J =3.1 Hz, H-3); δ C 77.2, 73.6, and 66.4], and three nonprotonated carbons (one oxygenated carbon at δ C 75.8) ( Tables 1 and 2 ). The above analysis implied that compound 2 was a benzodihydrofuran-type cassane diterpenoids with three acetoxy groups. The HMBC correlations from H-1, H-2, and H-3 to the carbonyls of 1-OAc ( δ C 169.7 and 21.3), 2-OAc ( δ C 170.1 and 20.9), and 3-OAc ( δ C 169.8 and 21.0), respectively, along with the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-1/H-2/H-3 ( Fig. 2 ), suggested the location of three acetoxy groups at C-1, C-2, and C-3. One hydroxy group attached to C-5 ( δ C 75.8) in 2 was deduced by the HMBC correlations from H 2 -6 ( δ H 2.02) and H 3 -19 ( δ H 1.27) to C-5. The ROESY correlations ( Fig. 3 ) between H-1 and H 3 - 20, H-2 and H 3 -20, H-2 and H 3 -19 indicated that H-1, H-2, H 3 -19, and H 3 -20 were β -oriented. The α -axial orientation of the 3-OAc was deduced by the small coupling constant of J 2,3 (3.1 Hz). Furthermore, the ROESY correlation of H 3 -18 and 5-OH indicated that they were α -oriented. Finally, the absolute configuration of compound 2 was determined to be identical to 11 by their similar experimental ECD curves and specific rotation values ( Fig. 5 ). The planar structure and absolute configuration of 11 was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis using Cu Kα radiation with a Flack parameter 0.03 (2) ( Fig. 4 ). Thus, compound 2 was established as (1 S ,2 R ,3 S ,5 R ,10 S )- 1,2,3-triacetoxy-12, 16-epoxycassa-8,11,13-trien-5-ol. In addition, ε -Caesalpin-VII ( 11 ) was afforded by acid treatment of ε -caesalpin in 1967. The natural origin and 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 11 were reported for the first time in the current study ( Tables 2 and 3 ).

Cassabonducin C ( 3 ) was obtained as white amorphous powder, and was assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 26 O 3 on the basis of an HRESIMS [M+Na] + ion at m/z 337.1780 (calcd 337.1774). The absorptions in the IR spectrum appeared at 3441, 1732, and 1638 cm 1 attributable to hydroxy, ester carbonyl, and double bond groups, respectively. The 1 H-NMR spectrum of 3 displayed signals corresponding to four tertiary methyls ( δ H 2.38 s , 1.31 s , 1.14 s , and 1.12 s ), an oxygen-substituted methine ( δ H 4.57, br s, H-1), an aromatic proton ( δ H 7.39, br s, H-11), and a 1,2-disubstituted furan ring ( δ H 7.54, d, J =1.8, H-16 and 6.74, d, J =1.8, H-15) ( Table 1 ). The 13 C-NMR spectrum of 3 showed 22 carbon signals ( Table 2 ) attributable to four methyls, four aliphatic methylenes, four methines (one oxygenated at δ C 73.5, one aromatic at δ C 104.5, and two olefinic at δ C 144.4, 105.2), and eight nonprotonated carbons (one oxygenated at δ C 77.2 and five aromatic at δ C 153.9, 141.1, 129.3, 125.8, 104.5). The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data for 3 closely resembled those of caesalpinin MP (
), except for one hydroxy group at C-1 ( δ C 73.5) in 3 instead of the acetoxy unit in the latter. This assumption was verified by the correlations from H 2 -2 ( δ H 2.22 and 1.96) and H 3 -20 ( δ H 1.31) to C- 1 in the HMBC spectrum. The correlations of H-1/H 3 -20, H-2 β /H 3 -20, and H-2 β /H 3 -19, and 5-OH/H 3 -18 were observed in the ROESY spectrum, suggesting the β -orientations of H-1, H 3 -19, and H 3 -20, whereas the α -orientations of 5-OH and H 3 -18. The absolute configuration of 3 were established as 1 S , 5 R , 10 S based on the similar ECD absorption curves of 3 and 12 ( Fig. 5 ). The structure and absolute configuration of 12 was assigned by single-crystal X-ray diffraction in the current study ( Fig. 4 ). Hence, the structure of 3 was identified as (1 S ,5 R ,10 S )-12,16-epoxycassa-8,11,13,2,15-tetraen-1, 5-diol. In addition, the 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) of 12 was reported for the first time in this study.

Cassabonducin D ( 4 ) was assigned the molecular formula C 24 H 34 O 6 by the pseudomolecular ion peak at m/z 441.2260 [M+Na] + (calcd 441.2248) in HRESIMS spectrum. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 4 ( Tables 1 and 2 ) showed a close resemblance to those of caesalpinin K ( 14 ) (
), with the only difference being the presence of an extra acetyl group ( δ H 2.07 s , δ C 170.8 and 22.1.) in 4 . The deshielded C-7 resonance (Δ δ C +54.8) indicated that the additional acetoxy group was located at C-7, which was further supported by the HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) between H-7 ( δ H 5.38) and the acetyl carbonyl ( δ C 170.8). The ROESY cross-peaks ( Fig. 3 ) of H-7 and H 3 -18 with OH-5, and of H-7 and H-9 with H 3 -17 suggested that H-7 was α -oriented. The absolute configuration of 4 was subsequently determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 4 ). Ultimately, the structure of 4 was assigned as (1 S ,5 R ,7 S ,8 S ,9 S ,10 S ,14 R )-1,7-diacetoxy-12,16-epoxycassa-12, 15-dien-5-ol.
a Measured at 500 MHz.
b Measured at 600 MHz.

Cassabonducin E ( 5 ) possessed a molecular formula of C 24 H 34 O 6 as deduced from HRESIMS ( m/z 441.2243 [M+Na] + ; calcd 441.2248) and 13 C NMR data. Examination the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) revealed that the structure of 5 was closely related to that of 4 , except for a notable change involving that an acetoxy group at C- 7 in 4 moved to C-6 ( δ C 73.4) in 5 . This prediction was proved through the HMBC correlations from H-6 ( δ H 5.35) to the acetyl carbonyl ( δ C 170.5), along with the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-6/H 2 -7/H-8/H-9. H-6 was assigned as β -oriented by the ROESY correlations of H-6 with H-8 and H 3 -20. The relative configurations of remaining stereogenic centers of 5 were found to be the same as those of 4 by the ROESY data. The ECD spectrum of 5 showed a positive Cotton effect at 220 nm ( Δε +1.7) consistent with that of 4 ( Fig. 5 ), indicating the 1 S ,5 R ,6 S ,8 S ,9 S ,10 S ,14 R - configuration. Hence, the structure of 5 was suspected as (1 S ,5 R ,6 S ,8 S ,9 S ,10 S ,14 R )-1,6-diacetoxy-12,16-epoxycassa-12,15-dien-5-ol.

Cassabonducin F ( 6 ) was isolated as colorless crystals with the molecular formula C 24 H 32 O 7 on basis of HRESIMS data at m/z 455.2037 [M+Na] + (calcd 455.2040), corresponding to nine degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3571 and 1736 cm 1 , which indicated the existence of hydroxy and carbonyl functionalities, respectively. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of 6 were almost identical to those of 4 , with the only distinction being that 6 possessed a formyl group at C-17 ( δ C 199.9) instead of a methyl group in 4 . This assertion was validated by HMBC correlations from H-17 ( δ H 9.22) to C-14 ( δ C 52.9) and from H-8 ( δ H 2.27) and H-14 ( δ H 3.21) to C-17. The ROESY correlations between H-1 and H 3 -20, H-8 and H-17, H-8 and H 3 -20 indicated that H-1, H-8, H 3 -17, and H 3 -20 were β -oriented. Furthermore, the ROESY correlations of H-7/H-9, H-7/H-14, H-9/H-14, and H-9/5-OH indicated that they were α -oriented. Colorless crystals of 6 were obtained from MeOH. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis with Cu Kα radiation ( Fig. 4 ) of 6 unequivocally established its absolute configuration as 1 S , 5 R , 7 S , 8 R , 9 S , 10 S , 14 S. Thus, compound 6 was established as (1 S ,5 R ,7 S ,8 R ,9 S ,10 S ,14 S )-1,7-diacetoxy-5-hydroyl-12,16-epoxycassa-12,15-dien-17-al.

Cassabonducin G ( 7 ) had a molecular formula of C 24 H 32 O 8 on the basis of an HRESIMS [M+Na] + ion at m/z 471.1986 (calcd 471.1989), implying nine indices of hydrogen deficiency. IR spectrum showed absorption bands for hydroxy ( 3436 cm -1 ) and carbonyl (1746 and 1715 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 7 ( Tables 2 and 3 ) displayed signals corresponding to 1,2-disubstituted furan ring ( δ H 6.39 and 7.26, both d, J =1.7 Hz; δ C 142.1 and 108.8), two acetyl groups ( δ H 2.05 s , 1.96 s ; δ C 21.9, 172.7 and 21.7, 172.1), four tertiary methyls, three aliphatic methylenes, four methines [cluding two oxymethines ( δ H 5.59 br s and 5.78 br s; δ C 77.1 and 75.0)], and four nonprotonated carbons [including two oxygenated ones ( δ C 83.7, 69.5) and one ketone carbonyl ( δ C 214.8)]. The aforementioned NMR data revealed that 7 was also a cassane diterpenoid and was structurally similar to caesalmin D (
). Compared with caesalmin D, a ketone carbonyl rather than an oxymethine was located at C-1 for 7 , which was confirmed by the HMBC correlations of H 2 -2 ( δ H 2.89 and 2.17) and H 3 -20 ( δ H 1.52) with C-1 ( δ C 214.8). Because H-6 and H-7 were broad singlet, the related correlations could not be detected in ROESY spectrum. Fortunately, single crystals were obtained from MeOH. Through the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis using Cu-K α radiation with the Flack parameter 0.02 (3) unambiguously determined the absolute configuration as 5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,8 R ,9 S ,10 R , 14 R ( Fig. 4 ). Accordingly, the structure of compound 7 was elucidated as (5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,8 R ,9 S ,10 R , 14 R )-6,7-diacetoxy-5,14-dihydroxy-12,16-epoxycassa-1-one.

Cassabonducin H ( 8 ) was isolated as colorless oil, and its molecular formula C 23 H 34 O 7 was established by HRESIMS ( m/z 445.2199 [M+Na] + , calcd 445.2197). The IR spectrum showed characteristic absorption bands of hydroxyl (3580 cm-1 ) and ester carbonyl ( 1740 cm 1 ). The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 2 and 3 ) were closely related to those of caesalpinin L (
), except that a hydroxy group at C- 7 in 8 replaced the acetoxy moiety in caesalpinin L and that the methyl group of C- 17 in caesalpinin L was oxidized into a hydroxymethyl group in 8 . In addition, the presence of one methoxy group ( δ H 3.20 s ; δ C 53.1) at C-14 (75.9) in 8 was observed. These differences were confirmed by the HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from H-7 ( δ H 4.40) to C-6 ( δ C 35.2) and C-8 ( δ C 48.5), from H 2 -17 ( δ H 3.74 and 3.94) to C-8, C-13 ( δ C 115.8), and C-14 ( δ C 75.9), and from OCH 3 to C-14. The ROESY correlations ( Fig. 3 ) between H-1 and H 3 -20, H-8 and H 2 -17, H-8 and H 3 -20 indicated these protons were β -oriented. Furthermore, the ROESY correlations of OCH 3 and H-7 with H-9, and of H-7 and H 3 -18 with 5-OH indicated the α -orientation. The experimental and calculated ECD spectra showed good agreement ( Fig. 6 ), indicating that the absolute configuration of 8 was 1 S ,5 R ,7 S ,8 S ,9 S ,10 S ,14 R . Consequently, the structure of 8 was identified as (1 S ,5 R ,7 S ,8 S ,9 S ,10 S ,14 R )-1-acetoxy-14-methoxy-12,16-epoxycassa-8,11,13-trien-5,7,14-triol.

The molecular formula of cassabonducin I ( 9 ) were determined as C 23 H 32 O 8 , on the basis of a pseudomolecular ion peak at m/z 459.1995 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 23 H 32 O 8 Na, 459.1989) in the HRESIMS spectrum, indicating eight degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum exhibited absorptions for hydroxy (3569 cm-1 ) and carbonyl ( 1733 cm 1 ) functionalities. Their 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 2 and 3 ) implied that 9 possessed similar structure as that of caesalpinin M ( 15 ) (
). The only difference included one hydroxy group linked to C-7 ( δ C 78.7) in 9 instead of an acetoxy group in 15 . This finding was performed by the presence of the HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from H-7 ( δ H 3.74) to C-6 ( δ C 76.0) and C-8 ( δ C 40.3), and the absence the HMBC correlation between H-7 ( δ H 5.28) and the acetyl carbonyl, as well as the upfield-shifted C-7 (Δ δ C +3.5) resonance. In ROESY spectrum ( Fig. 3 ), the correlations of 5-OH/H-9, H-9/H-14, H-7/H-14, and 5-OH/H 3 -18 indicated the α -orientations of 5-OH, H-7, H-9, and H-14. In addition, the ROESY cross-peaks of H-1/H 3 -20, H-8/H-6, H-6/H 3 -19, and H-8/H 3 -20 were in agreement with the β -orientations of these protons. Finally, crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analyses were obtained from MeOH. The complete structure and absolute configuration were determined through the X-ray diffraction with Cu K α radiation ( Fig. 4 ). Hence, the structure of 9 was identified as methyl (1 S ,5 R ,6 S ,7 R , 8 R ,9 S ,10 S ,14 S )-1-acetoxy-5,6,7-trihydroxy-12,16-epoxycassa-14-oate.

Cassabonducin J ( 10 ) was found to possess a molecular formula of C 25 H 34 O 10 , as deduced from its HRESIMS data at m/z 517.2044 [M+Na] + (calcd 517.2050). Comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data ( Tables 2 and 3 ) of 10 with those of 9 indicated that they were structural analogs. The main differences were the interchanged hydroxy and acetoxy groups at C-1 and C-7, and the presence of one more acetoxy group at C- 2 in 10 . HMBC correlation from H-7 ( δ H 5.23) to the acetyl carbonyl ( δ C 172.4) confirmed the position of one acetoxy group at C-7. However, the correlation from H-2 ( δ H 5.28) to another acetyl carbonyl ( δ C 170.2) was not observed in HMBC spectrum. Fortunately, the acetoxy group ( δ H 2.11 s ; δ C 21.5, 170.2) attached to C-2 was determined by the HMBC correlations from 1-OH ( δ H 2.74), 5-OH ( δ H 3.88), and 6-OH ( δ H 2.11) to C-1 ( δ C 74.0), C-5 ( δ C 79.4), and C-6 ( δ C 74.7), respectively. The location of one hydroxy group at C-1 ( δ C 74.0) was further confirmed by the HMBC correlations from H-1 ( δ H 3.81) to C-2 and C-10 ( δ C 46.0), coupled with the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of 1-OH/H-1/H-2/H 2 -3. ROESY correlations from H-1 to H 3 -20 and from H-2 to H 3 -20 defined H-1 and H-2 as β -oriented. H-7 was inferred as α -oriented by the ROESY correlation of H-7/H-14 and of H-9/ H-14. The absolute configuration of 10 were determined as 1 R ,2 S ,5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,8 R ,9 S ,10 S , 14 S based on the similar ECD curve of 9 and 10 with negative Cotton effects at 205 and 227 nm ( Fig. 5 ). Accordingly, the structure of 10 was elucidated as methyl (1 R ,2 S ,5 R ,6 S ,7 R ,8 R ,9 S ,10 S ,14 S )-2,7-diacetoxy-1,5,6-trihydroxy-12,16- epoxycassa-14-oate.

sec.title: 2.2. LPS-induced NO inhibitory and α- glucosidase activity
sec.p: In the light of the structures and the anti-inflammatory activity, a preliminary structure activity relationship observation was made. The isolated cassane diterpenoids with benzodihydrofuran ( 2 and 11 ), benzofuran ( 3 and 12 ), furan ( 4–10 , 13–17 , 20 , and 21 ), and butenolide lactone ( 18 and 19 ) units were inactive (IC 50 > 50 μM). However, compound 1 exhibited potent inhibitory effect against NO production. These observations suggested that the α , β -unsaturated γ -lactone ring conjugated with an extra double bond between C-11 and C- 12 in 1 was important for its anti-inflammatory activity.

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p:
In the current study, ten previously undescribed cassane-type diterpenoids, along with eleven known analogs were isolated from the seed kernels of
C. bonduc
. The structures of undescribed compounds were elucidated by spectroscopic analysis, ECD calculations, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Interestingly, the hydroxylation or acetoxylation of these compounds shared the same relative configuration such as 1 α -OH/OAc, 2 α -OH/OAc, 5 α -OH, 6 α -OH/OAc, and 7 β -OH/OAc). In addition, bioassays displayed that compound 1 had potent inhibitory activity against LPS-induced nitric oxide (NO) production in RAW 264.7 macrophages.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p:
HRESIMS were performed on an Agilent 1290 UPLC/6540 Q-TOF spectrometer. UV spectra were obtained using a Shimadzu UV-2401A spectrophotometer. Optical rotations were measured with a Jasco P-1020 polarimeter. IR spectra were obtained by a Tensor 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. ECD spectra were measured on a Chirascan Circular Dichroism Spectrometer.1D ( 1 H, 13 C, and DEPT) and 2D ( 1 H– 1 H COSY, HSQC, HMBC, and ROESY) spectra were recorded on an Avance III 500 and AV 600 MHz spectrometer. Semi-preparative HPLC was performed on an Agilent 1200 apparatus equipped with a diode array detector and a Zorbax SB-C-18 (Agilent, 9.4 mm × 25 cm ) column. X-ray diffraction was performed on a Bruker APEX DUO diffractometer using graphitemonochromated Cu Kα radiation. MPLC was performed using a Lisui EZ Purifier III System ( Shanghai Lisui Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd., Shanghai , China ) coupled with UV detector. Column chromatography (CC) was performed using silica gel (100–200 and 200–300 mesh, Qingdao Marine Chemical Co. Ltd., Qingdao, China ) and MCI gel (CHP20P, 75–150 μm; Mitsubishi Chemical Corporation, Japan ). Fractions were monitored by TLC (GF254, Qingdao Marine Chemical Co. Ltd., Qingdao, China ), and spots were visualized by heating silica gel plates sprayed with 10% H 2 SO
4 in
EtOH. All solvents were distilled prior to use.

sec.title: 4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
Seeds of
Caesalpinia bonduc
(L.) Roxb. ( Fabaceae ) were purchased in
February 2016
from Anguo market of material medica, Hebei Province , People’ s Republic of China, and identified by Prof. Xiao Cheng, Kunming Institute of Botany ,
Chinese Academy of Sciences.
A voucher specimen (20160228b) was deposited with the State Key Laboratory of Phytochemistry and Plant Resources in West China , Kunming Institute of Botany , Chinese Academy of Sciences
.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
The powdered air-dried seeds of
C. bonduc
( 10 kg ) were extracted with 95% EtOH (3 × 15 L, 48 h each) at room temperature. Removal of the extracted solvent under reduced pressure yielded a residue, which was suspended in H 2 O and partitioned with EtOAc (4 × 2 L). The extract was filtered and concentrated under reduced pressure to give 169 g of residue, which was fractionated by MPLC (MCI gel), eluting with MeOH/H 2 O (70:30, 75:25, 80:20, 85:15, 90:10, 95:5, 100:0, v/v, 30 mL/min), to provide five fractions (A-E).

Fraction A ( 13.5 g ) was separated by CC over silica gel eluting with a step gradient of (CHCl 3 –MeOH, 100:1–7:3, v/v) to give three fractions (A1-A3). Subfraction A1 ( 2.9 g ) was further purified by silica gel CC eluting with petroleum ether (PE)-acetone (7:3, v/v) and semipreparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, 54:46, v/v, 3 mL/min) to afford compounds 12 ( 4.4 mg , t R = 13.9 min) and 4 ( 12.8 mg , t R = 18.6 min). Compound 21 ( 8.9 mg ) and 6 ( 4.2 mg ) were obtained after silica gel CC eluted with a CHCl 3 -acetone gradient system (50:1–9:1, v/v) from subfraction A2 ( 3.8 g ). Following the same purification procedure, compounds 1 ( 6.2 mg ), 11 ( 9.4 mg ), and 14 ( 10.3 mg ) were yielded from subfraction A3 ( 4.1 g ).

Fraction B ( 13.9 g ) was subjected to silica gel CC eluted with a PEacetone graent (30:1–6:4, v/v) to provide three subfractions (B1–B3). Subfraction B1 ( 4.6 g ) was further subjected to silica gel CC (PE-EtOAc, 100:1–9:1, v/v) and further purified by Sephadex LH-20 CC (MeOH) to give 15 ( 11.5 mg ) and 8 ( 7.3 mg ). Subfraction B3 ( 600 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, v/v, 3.0 mL/min) to obtain 9 ( 12.7 mg , t R 9.7 min), 3 ( 2.7 mg , t R 11.0 min), and 7 ( 4.2 mg , t R 16.5 min).

Fraction C ( 12.4 g ) was subjected to CC on silica gel eluting with a gradient of CHCl 3 -acetone (100:0–1:1) to give 17 ( 7.5 mg ), 18 (13.0 mg), and another two subfractions (C1–C2). Subfraction C1 ( 2.3 g ) was subjected to Sephadex LH-20 CC (MeOH) to give 10 (8.0 mg). Subfraction C2 ( 3.1 g ) was further applied to a silica gel CC (PE-EtOAc, 50:1–8:2, v/v) and then purified by semipreparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, 48:52, v/v) to obtain 2 ( 5.5 mg , t R = 10.2 min).

Fraction D ( 33.3 g ) was subjected to silica gel CC eluted with a PE-EtOAc gradient (80:1–8:2, v/v) to provide three subfractions (D1-D3). Subfraction D1 ( 3.5 g ) was further purified by a silica gel CC eluting with (PE-EtOAc, 8:2, v/v), and semipreparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, v/ v, 3 mL/min) to afford compounds 5 ( 5.8 mg , t R =14.2 min) and 13 ( 4.2 mg , t R = 11.6 min). Following the same purification procedure, compounds 7 ( 4.1 mg ), 16 ( 11.4 mg ), 19 ( 1.5 mg ), and 20 ( 3.8 mg ) were yielded from subfraction D3 ( 8.3 g ).

sec.title: 4.4. Crystallographic data of compounds 1, 4, 6, 7, 9, 11, and 12
sec.p:
Crystals of 1 , 4 , 6 , 7 , 9 , 11 , and 12 were all crystallized from MeOH at room temperature and individuals used for measurement on a Bruker APEX DUO diffractometer with graphite monochromater Cu Kα radiation. Crystal structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-2014 (
), expanded using difference Fourier technique, and refined with full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXS-2014. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atom was placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model.

sec.title: 4.5. ECD computational methods
4.6.1. Nitric oxide production inhibitory assay
4.6.2. α- glucosidase inhibitory assay
sec.p:
An enzyme-inhibitor screening model was chosen using 4-nitrophenol-α- D-glucopyranoside (PNPG) and slightly modified (
). Briefly, test compound (50 μ M), α- glucosidase solution (0.025 U/mL), phosphate buffer (pH 6.9), and PNPG (1 μ M) were incubated in 96-well plates at 37 ◦ C for 50 min. Absorbance at 405 nm was recorded on a microplate reader. Blank readings (no enzyme) were subtracted from each well, and the results were compared to the control. The quercetin was selected as the positive control. All the reactions were repeated three times. The inhibition rate (%) was calculated as (1- ODsample )/ ODcontrol blank × 100%.
